repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - First and Second Structural
            Adjustment, Public Management Capacity Building, and Private
            Sector Development and Capacity Building Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This Project Performance Assessment
            Report (PPAR) covers four lending operations to the Republic
            of Madagascar from 1996 to 1999, to assist in improving
            public management and creating a favorable environment for
            the private sector, with the overarching objectives of
            opening the economy to market forces and reducing poverty.
            The following lessons emerge from the assessment: design
            policy development operations in a flexible manner based
            either on a menu-based approach to tranche release, or
            preferably, on a programmatic series of one-tranche
            operations with prior actions; technical assistance
            operations for supporting reforms should be well focused and
            have limited objectives initially aimed at implementation
            bottlenecks; new institutions in Madagascar need continued
            assistance from the donor community; give consideration to
            reviving the Private Sector Support Fund or setting up a
            similar scheme to promote PSD ; and much greater attention
            than in the past should be given by the authorities and by
            the Bank to revenue mobilization and reallocation of public
            resources for poverty reduction.

6934129.trustfund:
TF023976-FAC CONSULTANT TRUST FUND (USD A/C),TF033791-GLOBAL - TELECOMMUNICATIONS,TF029419-PHRD-PRIVATE SECT.DEV. &
            CAPACITY BLDG.PROJ.,TF034502-MADAGASCAR - PRIVATE SECTOR
            DEV.& CAPACITY BUILDING,TF035001-MADAGASCAR - PRIVATE SECTOR DEVELOPMENT,TF040060-MADAGASCAR - PRIVATE SECTOR
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome of the
            Structural Adjustment Credit (SAC) Project is rated as
            satisfactory. Key lessons learned include: 1) Lack of client
            ownership of reforms will lead to their reversal. The SAC
            did prove to be an invaluable vehicle for advancing the
            development dialogue in Madagascar during times of political
            turmoil and economic reform backtracking. Through the
            preparation stage of the operation, the Bank used the
            potential credit as a means to engage the pro-reform
            elements in Madagascar and tailored its pitch to the
            political leadership when receptive or to analytical work
            when dialogue was slow. 2) The SAC should be viewed as a
            combination of the specific measures that were taken prior
            to Board presentation, and the commitments under the Letter
            of Development Policy to continue to execute the reforms.
            Bank adjustment operations shift towards the use of floating
            tranches, particularly in cases where the reform program is
            multi-faceted, and therefore subject to a differentiated
            pace of implementation. Conditionality should be specified
            in ways in which results are clearly identified and
            rewarded. 3) The operations reinforce the by-now-accepted
            view that weak institutional capacity needs to be fully
            factored into program design.
